info.piwai.funkyjfunctional
Class Funky

java.lang.Object
  info.piwai.funkyjfunctional.Funky

public abstract class Funky
extends java.lang.Object

FunkyJFunctional enables Java functional programming using method local class declarations and init blocks.

FunkyJFunctional integrates with Guava (the former google collections), but also provides shortcuts for some standard Java interfaces such as Runnable or Callable.

The Funky class is the main entry point to FunkyJFunctional. Therefore, most of the documentation for this project will be found here.

Contents

  • 1. Let's learn the funky way
  • 2. Various Funky ways
  • 3. A word of caution

1. Let's learn the funky way

Using FunkyJFunctional always involves two steps:

  • function declaration, as a method local class,
  • function instantiation, using the Funky class.

Function declaration

Let's declare an Adult predicate, that returns true if the given integer parameter is greater than 18. 

 // t is the input parameter, and r is the returned value.
 class Adult extends Pred<Integer> {{ r = t > 18; }}

To use this predicate, we need to instantiate it as a Guava Predicate that we can use in our code. 

 // Let's import Funky statically, as well as Guava's Iterables class, so that the code looks clearer
 import static info.piwai.funkyjfunctional.Funky.*;
 import static com.google.common.collect.Iterables.*;
 
 // Nothing too complex here
 List<Integer> values = Arrays.asList(16, 21);
 
 // the 'adults' Iterable contains only one element: '21'.
 Iterable<Integer> adults = filter(values, withPred(Adult.class));
 
 // The magic all happened in the withPred method, which created a Predicate:
 Predicate<Integer> adultPredicate = withPred(Adult.class);

2. Various Funky ways

To know more about what you can do with FunkyJFunctional, have a look at the various with*() methods of the Funky class.

Here is the list of the various funky ways currently provided by FunkyJFunctional:

  • For funky Functions, see Func and the withFunc(Class) method.
  • For funky Predicates, see Pred and the withPred(Class) method.
  • For funky Comparators, see Comp and the withComp(Class) method.
  • For funky Runnables, see the withRun(Class) method.
  • For funky Callables, see Call and the withCall(Class) method.
  • For funky Suppliers, see Supp and the withSupp(Class) method.

3. A word of caution

Warning: this paragraph is not clear and should be rewritten

You might notice that there are two withPred() methods: one that takes a class, and another one that takes a class and an instance object. In most cases, you will only need to use the first one. However, if the function declaration is done in an instance method (ie non static) AND this function accesses other instance methods or instance fields, then you should use the withPred() method that has two parameters. The second parameter is the instance on which the methods / fields will be called (ie, in most cases, 'this'). Otherwise, you will raise NullPointerExceptions.

Author:
Pierre-Yves Ricau (py.ricau at gmail.com), Florent Ramière
